title: Running GeneWalk
text: vignette first show Gene Walk behaves synthetic data, assumptions baked move onto using real data. want understand method detail, please check Ietswaart et al.. Let’s start synthetic data understand works… synthetic GeneWalk network designed testing benchmarking, signal genes forming coherent, degree-matched graph neighbourhoods noise genes spanning multiple ontology subtrees random. signal genes clear signal. Noise genes also still due nature synthetic data; however, lesser extent. data contains everything need initialise new GeneWalk: full_data term ontology, gene gene edges gene terms, mimicking relevant inputs. genes pathways testing later. gene identifiers including run. case, set “signal” genes serve positive control “noise genes” randomly distributed. term/pathway identifiers. Let’s initialise class. function generates node2vec embedding based network need generate background distribution testing purposes. generate three random permuted networks paper. used statistical testing. now need compare similarity Cosine similarities gene embeddings pathway embeddings check often larger ones background embedding, giving us p-values. Now can extract statistics: different metrics data Let’s explore signal synthetic data bit… observing … ?  can appreciate, Cosine similarities genes pathways signal data set much higher compared FALSE ones. Let’s look p-values  Similar pattern. TRUE signal ones nearly significant. Less noisy signal. signal noise data , expected due data. Let’s look genes passing FDR thresholds Basically, signal genes show significance associations gene pathways; less , noise genes. Let’s explore real data now. package provides builder factory generate objects. Within package, DuckDB contains Network resources STRING network extracted OpenTargets. SIGNOR network extracted OpenTargets. Reactome gene gene network extracted OpenTargets. Intact network extracted OpenTargets. combined network sources , based approach Barrio-Hernandez, et al.. Pathway terms Gene Ontology data extracted OBO files OBO foundry OpenTargets. Reactome pathway ontology gene pathway associations OpenTargets. Let’s use Gene Ontology combined network example. idea factory easily iterate various bags genes interest. Now let’s use factory look specifically MYC target genes (provided package) generate GeneWalkNetwork . can now use steps look genes simple way visualise initial results use plot_results() function. tell connectivity genes within bag genes (degree + 1 x-axis), number gene <> pathway connections significant specific gene number gene <> pathway connections. options plot individual genes significantly associated terms. want use provided data … ? case, can use simple wrapper class help . Let’s show case terms internally stored Reactome data. want now get full graph dt including everything verification: want subset bag genes interest, can run following: data can easily supplied now: , can run whole approach custom network.

title: Running GeneWalk
text: Let’s start synthetic data understand works… synthetic GeneWalk network designed testing benchmarking, signal genes forming coherent, degree-matched graph neighbourhoods noise genes spanning multiple ontology subtrees random. signal genes clear signal. text: genewalkR provides quite synthetic graph data sets testing exploration purposes, namely: Barbell graph: graph two distinct clusters Cavemen graph: graph distinct communities low probability connection . Stochastic blocks: densely connected graph communities; however, cross-edges compared previous graphs. Let’s load barbell graph. Let’s transform igraph first just look data like  can appreciate nice barbell graph two distinct groups. Now let’s run node2vec data. node2vec implementation based node2vec-rs, Rust-based implementation node2vec. default setting, use HIGHLY optimised version runs CPU SIMD-acceleration tolerated race condition (undefined behaviour low level terms) makes fast. issue underlying embeddings deterministic; however, structure underlying graph identified. really, really, really need deterministic results , set n_workers = 1L. want details node2vec actually works, please, check original paper Grover Leskovec. Let’s project data onto two dimensions via PCA visualise results  can appreciate, node2vec embeddings nicely identify two groups underlying graph. Let’s look graphs well known structures Visualisation graph structure igraph first:  Let’s check node2vec graph  graph, less defined communities edges across communities.  Let’s check node2vec graph  conclusion, node2vec generates embedding underlying network structure can use visualise data additional analysis (supervised tasks like package statistical testing gene <> pathway associations bag genes). Pending needs, can go high available workers make fast, really, really, really need similar embeddings every single time, can also choose disable parallelism training.
code: library(genewalkR) library(data.table) library(magrittr) library(ggplot2) # this creates a random data set with 20 nodes per barbell cluster barbell_data <- node2vec_test_data(   test_type = "barbell",   n_nodes_per_cluster = 20L ) g <- igraph::graph_from_data_frame(d = barbell_data$edges, directed = FALSE)  plot(g, vertex.label = NA) # run node2vec barbell_node2vec_results <- node2vec(   graph_dt = barbell_data$edges,   .verbose = TRUE )  # the parameters are controlled via a supplied parameter list, see code here str(params_node2vec()) #> List of 10 #>  $ p             : num 1 #>  $ q             : num 1 #>  $ walks_per_node: int 40 #>  $ walk_length   : int 40 #>  $ num_workers   : int 4 #>  $ batch_size    : int 256 #>  $ n_epochs      : int 20 #>  $ n_negatives   : int 5 #>  $ window_size   : int 2 #>  $ lr            : num 0.01  # this list can be supplied and tells node2vec how to run # run pca on the embeddings pca_results <- prcomp(barbell_node2vec_results, scale. = TRUE)  pca_dt <- as.data.table(pca_results$x[, 1:2], keep.rownames = "node") %>%   merge(., barbell_data$node_labels, by = "node")  pca_dt[, cluster := factor(cluster)]  ggplot(data = pca_dt, mapping = aes(x = PC1, y = PC2)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = cluster)) # generate the cavemen caveman_data <- node2vec_test_data(   test_type = "cavemen", n_clusters = 5L, p_between = 0.5 )  g <- igraph::graph_from_data_frame(d = caveman_data$edges, directed = FALSE)  plot(g, vertex.label = NA) # run node2vec cavemen_node2vec_results <- node2vec(   graph_dt = caveman_data$edges,   .verbose = TRUE )  # run pca on the embeddings pca_results <- prcomp(cavemen_node2vec_results, scale. = TRUE)  pca_dt <- as.data.table(pca_results$x[, 1:2], keep.rownames = "node") %>%   merge(., caveman_data$node_labels, by = "node")  pca_dt[, cluster := factor(cluster)]  ggplot(data = pca_dt, mapping = aes(x = PC1, y = PC2)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = cluster)) # generate the stochastic block graph stochastic_block_data <- node2vec_test_data(   test_type = "stochastic_block", n_clusters = 3L, p_between = 0.05 )  g <- igraph::graph_from_data_frame(   d = stochastic_block_data$edges,    directed = FALSE )  plot(g, vertex.label = NA) # run node2vec stochastic_blocks_node2vec_results <- node2vec(   graph_dt = stochastic_block_data$edges,   .verbose = TRUE )  # run pca on the embeddings pca_results <- prcomp(stochastic_blocks_node2vec_results, scale. = TRUE)  pca_dt <- as.data.table(pca_results$x[, 1:2], keep.rownames = "node") %>%   merge(., stochastic_block_data$node_labels, by = "node")  pca_dt[, cluster := factor(cluster)]  ggplot(data = pca_dt, mapping = aes(x = PC1, y = PC2)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = cluster))

title: Node2vec
text: genewalkR provides quite synthetic graph data sets testing exploration purposes, namely: Barbell graph: graph two distinct clusters Cavemen graph: graph distinct communities low probability connection . what: Calculate the pathway and gene statistics — calculate_genewalk_stats
title: Calculate the pathway and gene statistics — calculate_genewalk_stats
text: Calculates statistical significance gene-pathway associations using GeneWalk algorithm. gene-pathway pair, function computes p-values FDR corrections (globally across pairs per-gene) across multiple network permutations. final output includes mean values 95% confidence intervals statistics. function processes permutations Rust optimal performance, calculating cosine similarities gene pathway embeddings, determining p-values based null distributions randomised networks, applying Benjamini-Hochberg FDR corrections.

title: Calculate the pathway and gene statistics — calculate_genewalk_stats

title: Calculate the pathway and gene statistics — calculate_genewalk_stats
text: input object added stats property containing data.table following columns gene-pathway pair: gene - Gene identifier pathway - Pathway identifier avg_pval - Mean p-value across permutations pval_ci_lower, pval_ci_upper - 95% CI p-values avg_global_fdr - Mean global FDR across permutations global_fdr_ci_lower,global_fdr_ci_upper - 95% CI global FDR avg_gene_fdr - Mean gene-wise FDR across permutations gene_fdr_ci_lower,gene_fdr_ci_upper - 95% CI gene-wise FDR

code: generate_initial_emb(   object,   embd_dim = 8L,   node2vec_params = params_node2vec(),   directed = FALSE,   seed = 42L,   .verbose = TRUE )

title: Generate the initial graph embedding — generate_initial_emb
text: object GeneWalk class, please see GeneWalk(). embd_dim Integer. Size embedding dimensions create. Defaults 8L line authors recommendations. node2vec_params Named list. Contains node2vec parameters. list following elements: p - Numeric. Return parameter biased random walks. Defaults 1.0. q - Numeric. -parameter biased random walks. Defaults 1.0.. walks_per_node - Integer. Number random walks per node. Defaults  40L.. walk_length - Integer. Length random walk. Defaults 40L. num_workers - Number worker threads batching. Defaults 4L. note: graph generation, Rust use via Rayon backend available threads. batch_size - Integer. Batch size training. Defaults 256L. n_epochs - Integer. Number training epochs. title: Generate synthetic GeneWalk data — synthetic_genewalk_data
text: Generates synthetic network mimics real GeneWalk input data testing benchmarking. network consists three components: hierarchical ontology (tree structure lateral edges), gene--ontology annotations, protein-protein interactions (PPI). Signal genes annotated exclusively within single ontology subtree form PPI edges among , creating coherent graph neighbourhoods. Noise genes receive number annotations forced span multiple subtrees, PPI edges random across noise group. groups degree-matched significance driven annotation coherence rather connectivity alone.

title: Generate synthetic GeneWalk data — synthetic_genewalk_data
text: data_params Named list. Return params_genewalk_data(). seed Integer. Random seed. Defaults 42L.

title: Generate synthetic GeneWalk data — synthetic_genewalk_data
text: list following items: full_data data.table columns containing edges (ontology hierarchy, gene--pathway, PPI). gene_to_pathways data.table columns (gene) (pathway) gene--ontology annotation edges . gene_ids Character vector gene identifiers (signal noise). pathway_ids Character vector ontology term identifiers.
